did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Thirty scrapbooks containing letters, clippings, photographs, and printed materials relating to Corson's travels, life, and career; correspondence exchanged between Corson and colleagues on Shakespeare, Chaucer, Tennyson, Browning, and other figures of English literature; reviews of books and articles by Corson and other scholars; announcements, programs, letters, notes, and reviews pertaining to Corson's activities as public lecturer and reader; letters from friends and family members dealing chiefly with personal matters: health, progress of career, daily activities; one scrapbook devoted to spiritualism, including letters from and about Madame Helena Petrovna Blavatsky, co-founder of the American Theosophical Society. Unbound material includes large numbers of family letters with extensive comments on the early days of Cornell University and life in Ithaca, New York, accounts of the travels of Corson, his wife, Caroline, and their son Eugene, their daily work and activities; clippings, pamphlets, reprints of articles relating to Corson's work in the field of English literature and that of his son in medicine; drafts of lectures and articles; anatomical, physiological, and surgical drawings; photographs; a syllabus; and miscellaneous books. Also, a tape recorded interview with Signe Sjoegren conducted by Gould P. Colman concerning the activities of Corson during the last seven years of his life.

Correspondents include Louise Andrews, Matthew Arnold, Henry Ward Beecher, Madame Blavatsky, Edwin Booth, Robert Browning, Francis James Child, Mary Cowden Clarke, George William Curtis, Edward Everett, Willard Fiske, Jessie Fothergill, Horace Howard Furness, Frederick J. Furnivall, Daniel Coit Gilman, Samuel Stehman Haldeman, Edward Everett Hale, James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps, Bret Harte, Nathaniel Hawthorne, Oliver Wendell Holmes, William Dean Howells, Clement Mansfield Ingleby, William James, Pierre Janet, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, James Russell Lowell, John M. D. Meiklejohn, J. Parker Norris, Goldwin Smith, Andrew D. White, Walt Whitman, John Greenleaf Whittier, and Woodrow Wilson.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Thirty scrapbooks containing letters, clippings, photographs, and printed materials relating to Corson's travels, life, and career; correspondence exchanged between Corson and colleagues on Shakespeare, Chaucer, Tennyson, Browning, and other figures of English literature; reviews of books and articles by Corson and other scholars; announcements, programs, letters, notes, and reviews pertaining to Corson's activities as public lecturer and reader; letters from friends and family members dealing chiefly with personal matters: health, progress of career, daily activities; one scrapbook devoted to spiritualism, including letters from and about Madame Helena Petrovna Blavatsky, co-founder of the American Theosophical Society. Unbound material includes large numbers of family letters with extensive comments on the early days of Cornell University and life in Ithaca, New York, accounts of the travels of Corson, his wife, Caroline, and their son Eugene, their daily work and activities; clippings, pamphlets, reprints of articles relating to Corson's work in the field of English literature and that of his son in medicine; drafts of lectures and articles; anatomical, physiological, and surgical drawings; photographs; a syllabus; and miscellaneous books. Also, a tape recorded interview with Signe Sjoegren conducted by Gould P. Colman concerning the activities of Corson during the last seven years of his life.

Correspondents include Louise Andrews, Matthew Arnold, Henry Ward Beecher, Madame Blavatsky, Edwin Booth, Robert Browning, Francis James Child, Mary Cowden Clarke, George William Curtis, Edward Everett, Willard Fiske, Jessie Fothergill, Horace Howard Furness, Frederick J. Furnivall, Daniel Coit Gilman, Samuel Stehman Haldeman, Edward Everett Hale, James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps, Bret Harte, Nathaniel Hawthorne, Oliver Wendell Holmes, William Dean Howells, Clement Mansfield Ingleby, William James, Pierre Janet, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, James Russell Lowell, John M. D. Meiklejohn, J. Parker Norris, Goldwin Smith, Andrew D. White, Walt Whitman, John Greenleaf Whittier, and Woodrow Wilson.

controlaccess.head: Names:

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Hiram Corson papers, #14-12-449. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

emph.ref: Series IV. Eugene Rollins Corson material

scopecontent.p: Includes letters from Eugene, Pauline, and Caroline Corson. Note: some of the letters were written to Eugene or Mrs. Corson. Many letters refer to spiritualism.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes Henry Wadsworth Longfellow letters to Caroline Rollin Corson: March 9, 1855-Regrets his publisher declined the translation on grounds of expense of printing in foreign language. Information about certain poems. Grieved about misfortuen which has befallen them. Hopes her school will flourish; May 15, 1855- Glad she found publisher in N.Y. for "Hyperion" will gladly look at proof sheets; June 15, 1855- Offers use of his name if it will be of any service.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes Nathaniel Hawthorne letter, dated February 17, 1964: Hawthorne thanks Corson for gift of Chaucer's "Legende of Goode Women" with hopes expressed for American edition of Chaucer's "Canterbury Pilgrims" edited in the same manner. Also includes some printed pamphlets and posters for performances.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes address of Hiram Corson on occasion of his induction as professor at Girard College.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes James Russell Lowell letter, dated October 24, 1867, to "my dear child" in which he regrets delay in publishing Mr. Corson's work and gladly would double subscription if it would help.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes letter from Bret Harte, and letter from Edwin Booth with references to Hamlet.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes printed pamphlets and posters for performances, correspondence on Pauline's death.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes two letters from Robert Browning: one inviting the Corsons' to lunch and another setting a convenient time to call.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes a letter from Robert Browning expressing thanks and letter from Walt Whitman sending notes and mentioning Woodruff's visit. Also includes letter from Edward Everett Hale.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes land deed and letter from Gabrielle DeVeaux Clements regarding Corson's portrait.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes photograph of Shakespeare's gloves.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes letter from Prince Serge Wolkonsky.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes letter and poems by Gottfried Hult.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes letter to Caroline Corson from Dr. Silas Weir Mitchell.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes letter, dated November 18, 1903, from Woodrow Wilson congratulation Corson.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes letters from Hiram Corson to Eugene Corson regarding Robert Browning: "On Wednesday evening, I read to my spiritual visitors my reminiscences of Browning, who had asked for them at the previous sitting [i. e., seance]. There were present Ma, Pauline and the boys, Browning, Tennyson, Whitman, Longfellow, J. W. H. Myers, Mrs. Browning, and Mrs. White - eleven in all. I read for an hour and a quarter... Browning did the rapping during the reading... [His]raps were very loud, and sometimes there was a rapid succession of them, which I took to signify a special approval of what I was reading at the time - ... At the close of the reading there were loud raps by Browning which I took to signify his approval of the paper. It will make a chapter in my book of about 25 pages... " A separate letter refers to the seance and mentions that he read them to his "Sage Class" at Cornell.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes last will and testament of Hiram Corson

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes newspaper clippings and receipts.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Includes letter from Fannie Barrett Browning postponing an engagement with Mrs. Corson on account of husband's headache. Also contains newspaper clippings.

did.unittitle: Horace Howard Furnace letters to Hiram Corson
Letters from F.J. Childs and George Allen
Letters and clippings from H.R. Haweis
Letters from Louisa Andrews to the Corsons

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Letters concerning spiritualism, merits of various mediums, spread of faith, and Olcott-Blavatsky partnership. Also includes letter to Andrews from JM Roberts calling into question the motives of Helena Petrovna Blavatsky and Henry Steel Olcott.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Written by Blavatsky to Mrs. Caroline Corson (written in French and referring to Louisa Andrews), Alexander Akozokof introducing Mrs. Corson, and photostat of letter to Hiram.

did.unittitle: Letter to Madame Blavatsky from J. R. Buchanan

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Concerning articles on science and religion.

did.unittitle: Letter to Madame Blavatsky from Francis F. Lippitt

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Concerning the authenticity of the "materializations" in which Mr. and Mrs. Holmes and Dr. Child were involved; mentions the "deep disgrace" of Katie King; also refers to Professor Corson, Mrs. Andrews of Springfield, and Colonel Olcott.

did.unittitle: Letter to Madame Blavatsky from S. P. Stephens

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Concerning alleged spiritualist frauds of Henry T. Child. Refers to a couple named Holmes, to a Katie King, and a Mrs. White. Also signed by Francis J. Lippitt as witness

did.unittitle: Letters to Henry Steel Olcott from Emma H. Britten and J. M. Peebles
Letter to Hiram Corson from G.L. Ditson
Letters to Hiram Corson from V.A. Taylor
Letter to Hiram Corson from Luther Colby

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Luther Colby, editor of the Banner of Light, accepting for publication an article by Corsonattacking the American Theosophical Society

did.unittitle: Letters to Hiram Corson from Emilie G. Jones

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Emilie Jones, sister of Louisa Andrews, reporting on latter's health.

did.unittitle: Statement of William H. Westcott, concerning the seances of Mr. and Mrs. Holmes; witnessed by Francis J. Lippitt.
Letter from David Higham to Eugene R. Corson regarding Blavatsky photographs

scopecontent.p: Formerly on display in the A.D. White library
